\sphinxAtStartPar
Build Lilypond scores via \sphinxhref{https://github.com/Abjad/abjad}{Abjad} from Mutwo data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The following converter classes help to quantize and translate Mutwo data to
Western notation. Due to the complex nature of this task, Mutwo tries to offer as
many optional arguments as possible through which the user can affect the conversion
routines. The most important class and best starting point for organising a conversion
setting is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEventToAbjadVoiceConverter}}.
If one wants to build complete scores from within mutwo, the module offers the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NestedComplexEventToAbjadContainerConverter}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Known bugs and limitations:}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Indicators attached to rests which follow another rest won’t be translated to
\sphinxtitleref{abjad}. This behaviour happens because the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEventToAbjadVoiceConverter}}
ties rests before converting the data to \sphinxtitleref{abjad} objects.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Quantization can be slow and not precise. Try both quantization classes.
Change the parameters. Use different settings and classes for different
parts of your music.

\end{enumerate}

This default class simply checks if the passed Mutwo object belongs to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.ext.parameters.pitches.WesternPitch}}. If it does, Mutwo
will initialise the Abjad Pitch from the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name}} attribute.
Otherwise Mutwo will simply initialise the Abjad Pitch from the
objects \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{frequency}} attribute.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If users desire to make more complex conversions (for instance
due to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scordatura}} or transpositions of instruments), one can simply
inherit from this class to define more complex cases.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{abjad.Voice}} object, appropriate to Western notation standards.

of previous tempo indications and it will write ‘a tempo’ when returning to the
same tempo after ritardandi or accelerandi.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Abstract base class for Abjad attachments which behave like a toggle.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In Western notation one can differentiate between elements which only get
notated if they change (for instance dynamics, tempo) and elements which
have to be notated again and again (for instance arpeggi or tremolo).
Attachments that inherit from {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.abjad_parameters:mutwo.abjad_parameters.abc.ToggleAttachment}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ToggleAttachment}}}}} represent elements
which only get notated if their value changes.

\index{random\_walk\_noise() (in module mutwo.common\_generators)@\spxentry{random\_walk\_noise()}\spxextra{in module mutwo.common\_generators}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/mutwo.common_generators:mutwo.common_generators.random_walk_noise}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{random\_walk\_noise}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{x0}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{n}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{dt}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{delta}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{out}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{random\_state}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Generate an instance of Brownian motion (i.e. the Wiener process).
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{x0}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}) \textendash{} the initial condition(s) (i.e. position(s)) of the Brownian motion.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{n}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} the number of steps to take

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{dt}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}) \textendash{} the time step

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{delta}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}) \textendash{} delta determines the “speed” of the Brownian motion.  The random variable
of the position at time t, X(t), has a normal distribution whose mean is
the position at time t=0 and whose variance is delta**2*t.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{out}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Optional}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{array}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}) \textendash{} If \sphinxtitleref{out} is not None, it specifies the array in which to put the
result.  If \sphinxtitleref{out} is None, a new numpy array is created and returned.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{random\_state}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Optional}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}) \textendash{} set the random seed of the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}random generator.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A numpy array of floats with shape \sphinxtitleref{x0.shape + (n,)}.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{array}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
X(t) = X(0) + N(0, delta**2 * t; 0, t)

\sphinxAtStartPar
where N(a,b; t0, t1) is a normally distributed random variable with mean a and
variance b.  The parameters t0 and t1 make explicit the statistical
independence of N on different time intervals; that is, if {[}t0, t1) and
{[}t2, t3) are disjoint intervals, then N(a, b; t0, t1) and N(a, b; t2, t3)
are independent.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Written as an iteration scheme,
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
X(t + dt) = X(t) + N(0, delta**2 * dt; t, t+dt)
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If \sphinxtitleref{x0} is an array (or array\sphinxhyphen{}like), each value in \sphinxtitleref{x0} is treated as
an initial condition, and the value returned is a numpy array with one
more dimension than \sphinxtitleref{x0}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the initial value \sphinxtitleref{x0} is not included in the returned array.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{This code has been copied from the scipy cookbook:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxurl{https://scipy-cookbook.readthedocs.io/items/BrownianMotion.html}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Python implementation of Michael Edwards activity level algorithm.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Activity Levels is a concept derived from Michael Edwards.
Quoting Michael Edwards, Activity Levels are an \sphinxhref{https://michael-edwards.org/sc/robodoc/activity-levels\_lsp.html\#robo23}{“object for determining
(deterministically) on a call\sphinxhyphen{}by\sphinxhyphen{}call basis whether a process is active
or not (boolean).  This is determined by nine 10\sphinxhyphen{}element lists
(actually three versions of each) of hand\sphinxhyphen{}coded 1s and 0s, each list
representing an ‘activity\sphinxhyphen{}level’ (how active the process should be).
The first three 10\sphinxhyphen{}element lists have only one 1 in them, the rest being zeros.
The second three have two 1s, etc. Activity\sphinxhyphen{}levels of 0 and 10 would return
never active and always active respectively.”}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example:}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{mutwo}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{generators} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{edwards}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{activity\PYGZus{}levels} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{edwards}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ActivityLevel}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{activity\PYGZus{}levels}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} activity level 0 will always return False}
\PYG{g+go}{False}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{activity\PYGZus{}levels}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} activity level 10 will always return True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{activity\PYGZus{}levels}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} activity level 7 will mostly return True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{tuple}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{activity\PYGZus{}levels}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{(True, False, True, True, False, True, True, False, True, True)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Furthermore it may be helpful to override the following method
(even though there is a valid working implementation):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\color{red}\bfseries{}:method:\textasciigrave{}Backtracking.element\_list\_to\_solution\textasciigrave{}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Please see the methods documentation for more details.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The implementation of this backtracking algorithm makes a distinction
between an element list and a solution. A solution is created by an
element list. A solution is the output a user wants to get, but
an element list is an object which is used internally in order to
solve the problem. When implementing a backtracking algorithm by
using this interface the user doesn’t have to make the distinction
between both (and in this case treat both in the same way).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The most common use case for this distinction is by having a set of
items which can appear in the solution and a list of indices which
item of set shall be used. In this  case the element\_list is actually
a list of indices. This use case is implemented in the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.common_generators:mutwo.common_generators.IndexBasedBacktracking}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IndexBasedBacktracking}}}}} class.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.chessprogramming.org/Backtracking}{Bitner and Reingold {[}2{]} credit Derrick H. Lehmer with first using the
term ‘backtrack’ in the 1950s.}.

The main reason for this constant is a mypy issue with Pythons buildin
{[}numbers module{]}(\sphinxurl{https://docs.python.org/3/library/numbers.html}) which
is documented {[}here{]}(\sphinxurl{https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/3186}). Mypy
doesn’t accept numbers abstract base classes. Until numbers will be
supported users have to define their own typing data for general number
classes. PEP 3141 recommends users to simply annotate arguments with
‘float’, but this wouldn’t include \sphinxtitleref{fractions.Fraction} which is often
necessary in musical contexts (as github user arseniiv also remarked).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Abstract base class for Converter which handle mutwo events.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This class helps building new classes which convert mutwo events
with few general private methods (and without adding any new public
method). Converting mutwo event often involves the same pattern:
due to the nested structure of an Event, the converter has
to iterate through the different layers until it reaches leaves
(any class that inherits from {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SimpleEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SimpleEvent}}}}}).
This common iteration process and the different time treatment
between {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SequentialEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SequentialEvent}}}}} and
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SimultaneousEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SimultaneousEvent}}}}} are implemented in
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_converters:mutwo.core_converters.abc.EventConverter}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EventConverter}}}}}.  For writing a new EventConverter class,
one only has to override the abstract method \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_convert\_simple\_event()}}
and the abstract method \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{convert()}} (where one will perhaps call
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_convert\_event()}}.).

\index{destructive\_copy() (SimpleEvent method)@\spxentry{destructive\_copy()}\spxextra{SimpleEvent method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SimpleEvent.destructive_copy}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{destructive\_copy}}}{}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Adapted deep copy method that returns a new object for every leaf.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It’s called ‘destructive’, because it forgets potential repetitions of
the same object in compound objects. Instead of reproducing the original
structure of the compound object that shall be copied, every repetition
of the same reference will return a new unique independent object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The following example shall illustrate the difference between copy.deepcopy
and destructive\_copy:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{copy}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{mutwo} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{core\PYGZus{}events}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}0} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{core\PYGZus{}events}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SimpleEvent}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{core\PYGZus{}events}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SimpleEvent}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}sequential\PYGZus{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{core\PYGZus{}events}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SequentialEvent}\PYG{p}{(}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }    \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}0}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{deepcopied\PYGZus{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{copy}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{deepcopy}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}sequential\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{destructivecopied\PYGZus{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}sequential\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{destructive\PYGZus{}copy}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{deepcopied\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{duration} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} setting the duration of the first event}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{destructivecopied\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{duration} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} return True because the first and the third objects share the same}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} reference (both are the same copy of \PYGZsq{}my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}0\PYGZsq{})}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{deepcopied\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{duration} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{deepcopied\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{duration}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} return False because destructive\PYGZus{}copy forgets the shared reference}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{destructivecopied\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{duration} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{destructivecopied\PYGZus{}event}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{duration}

or with points. If the sequence is filled with points, the points

a changing value. Any event class can be used. It is
more important that the used event classes fit with the functions
passed in the following parameters.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Adapted deep copy method that returns a new object for every leaf.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It’s called ‘destructive’, because it forgets potential repetitions of
the same object in compound objects. Instead of reproducing the original
structure of the compound object that shall be copied, every repetition
of the same reference will return a new unique independent object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The following example shall illustrate the difference between copy.deepcopy
and destructive\_copy:

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{core\PYGZus{}events}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SimpleEvent}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}sequential\PYGZus{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{core\PYGZus{}events}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SequentialEvent}\PYG{p}{(}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }    \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}simple\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}0}\PYG{p}{]}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Classes and functions that generate data with the potential of artistic use.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The module is organised in different submodules where each submodule is named after the first known
person who introduced the respective algorithms. Unlike the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.converters}} module the entered
data and the resulting data can be very different in type and form.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The term ‘generators’ simply labels the functionality of the module and shouldn’t be confused with the Python
term for specific functions with the ‘yield’ keyword.

Abstract base class for all parameters which are defined by one number.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Classes which inherit from this base class have to override
the same methods and properties as one have to override
when inheriting from {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_parameters:mutwo.core_parameters.abc.SingleValueParameter}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SingleValueParameter}}}}}.

Furthermore the property \sphinxtitleref{digit\_to\_round\_to\_count}
can be overridden. This should return an integer or \sphinxtitleref{None}.
If it returns an integer it will first round two numbers
before comparing them with the \sphinxtitleref{==} or \sphinxtitleref{\textless{}} or \sphinxtitleref{\textless{}=} or \sphinxtitleref{\textgreater{}}
or \sphinxtitleref{\textgreater{}=} operators.
The default implementation always returns {\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}}None.

{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_parameters:mutwo.core_parameters.abc.Duration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Duration}}}}} classes in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_parameters:module-mutwo.core_parameters}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_parameters}}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
When returning the \sphinxtitleref{duration\_in\_floats} property all mentioned events will
round their actual duration if the duration type is float. This
behaviour has been added with version 0.28.1 to avoid floating
point rounding errors which could occur in all duration related
methods of the different event classes (as it can happen in
for instance the {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.abc.ComplexEvent.squash_in}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.abc.ComplexEvent.squash\_in()}}}}}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The ‘add\_copy\_option’ decorator adds the ‘mutate’ keyword argument
to the decorated method. If ‘mutate’ is set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{False}}, the decorator deep
copies the respective object, then applies the called method on the new
copied object and finally returns the copied object. This can be useful
for methods that by default mutate its object. When adding this method,
it is up to the user whether the original object shall be changed
and returned (for mutate=True) or if a copied version of the object with
the respective mutation shall be returned (for mutate=False).

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Yields tuples of (factor, count) where each factor is unique and usually
prime, and count is an integer 1 or larger.
The factors are prime, except under the following circumstances: if the
argument n is negative, \sphinxhyphen{}1 is included as a factor; if n is 0 or 1, it
is given as the only factor. For all other integer n, all of the factors
returned are prime.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{factors}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{11}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{[(3, 1), (7, 3), (11, 1)]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This class helps generating score files for the \sphinxhref{http://www.csounds.com/}{“domain\sphinxhyphen{}specific computer
programming language for audio programming” Csound}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.csound_converters:mutwo.csound_converters.EventToCsoundScore}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EventToCsoundScore}}}}} extracts data from mutwo Events and assign it to
specific p\sphinxhyphen{}fields. The mapping of Event attributes to p\sphinxhyphen{}field values has
to be defined by the user via keyword arguments during class initialization.

\sphinxAtStartPar
By default, mutwo already maps the following p\sphinxhyphen{}fields to the following values:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
p1 (instrument name) to 1

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
p2 (start time) to the absolute start time of the event

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
p3 (duration) to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{duration}} attribute of the event

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If p2 shall be assigned to the absolute entry delay of the event,
it has to be set to None.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.csound_converters:mutwo.csound_converters.EventToCsoundScore}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EventToCsoundScore}}}}} ignores any p\sphinxhyphen{}field that returns
any unsupported p\sphinxhyphen{}field type (anything else than a string
or a number). If the returned type is a string, {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.csound_converters:mutwo.csound_converters.EventToCsoundScore}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EventToCsoundScore}}}}}
automatically adds quotations marks around the string in the score file.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All p\sphinxhyphen{}fields can be overwritten in the following manner:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{mutwo} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{csound\PYGZus{}converters}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}converter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{csound\PYGZus{}converters}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{EventToCsoundScore}\PYG{p}{(}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }    \PYG{n}{p1}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }    \PYG{n}{p4}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pitch}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{frequency}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }    \PYG{n}{p5}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{volume}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{accidental\_glyph\_tuple}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{tuple}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{...}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}) \textendash{} The name of accidental glyphs that should

Furthermore one can find mappings from mutwo data to Ekmelos glyph
names in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRIME\_AND\_EXPONENT\_AND\_TRADITIONAL\_ACCIDENTAL\_TO\_ACCIDENTAL\_GLYPH\_DICT}}

\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{deviation\_in\_cents}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}) \textendash{} How many cents shall an altered pitch differ from
its diatonic / natural counterpart.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{available\_diatonic\_pitch\_index\_tuple}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Optional}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{tuple}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{...}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{optional}}) \textendash{} Sometimes one
may want to define accidentals which are only available for certain
diatonic music\_parameters. For this case, one can use this argument

will be added to all seven diatonic music\_parameters.

Class for rendering standard midi files (SMF) from mutwo data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Mutwo offers a wide range of options how the respective midi file shall
be rendered and how mutwo data shall be translated. This is necessary due
to the limited and not always unambiguous nature of musical encodings in
midi files. In this way the user can tweak the conversion routine to her
or his individual needs.

{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SimpleEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SimpleEvent}}}}} a tuple that contains pitch objects

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{simple\_event\_to\_volume}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Callable}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.ext.parameters.abc.Volume}}. By default it asks the Event for
its \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{volume}} attribute (because by default
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.events.music.NoteLike}} objects are expected).
When using different Event classes than \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NoteLike}} with a

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

from a simple event. By default no control messages are generated. If the

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{midi\_file\_type}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} Can either be 0 (for one\sphinxhyphen{}track midi files) or 1 (for
synchronous multi\sphinxhyphen{}track midi files). Mutwo doesn’t offer support for generating
type 2 midi files (midi files with asynchronous tracks).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{available\_midi\_channel\_tuple}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{tuple}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{...}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}) \textendash{} tuple containing integer where each integer
represents the number of the used midi channel. Integer can range from 0 to 15.
Higher numbers of available\_midi\_channel\_tuple (like all 16) are recommended when
rendering microtonal music. It shall be remarked that midi\sphinxhyphen{}channel 9 (or midi
channel 10 when starting to count from 1) is often ignored by several software
synthesizer, because this channel is reserved for percussion instruments.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{distribute\_midi\_channels}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} This parameter is only relevant if more than one
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SequentialEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEvent}}}}} is passed to the convert method.
If set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{True}} each {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SequentialEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEvent}}}}}
only makes use of exactly n\_midi\_channel (see next parameter).
If set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{False}} each converted \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEvent}} is allowed to make use of all
available channels. If set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{True}} and the amount of necessary MidiTracks is
higher than the amount of available channels, mutwo will silently cycle through
the list of available midi channel.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{n\_midi\_channels\_per\_track}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} This parameter is only relevant for
distribute\_midi\_channels == True. It sets how many midi channels are assigned
to one SequentialEvent. If microtonal chords shall be played by
one SequentialEvent (via pitch bending messages) a higher number than 1 is
recommended. Defaults to 1.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{mutwo\_pitch\_to\_midi\_pitch}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.midi_converters:mutwo.midi_converters.MutwoPitchToMidiPitch}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MutwoPitchToMidiPitch}}}}}) \textendash{} class to convert from mutwo pitches
to midi pitches. Default to {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.midi_converters:mutwo.midi_converters.MutwoPitchToMidiPitch}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MutwoPitchToMidiPitch}}}}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ticks\_per\_beat}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} Sets the timing precision of the midi file. From the mido
documentation: “Typical values range from 96 to 480 but some use even more
ticks per beat”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{instrument\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Sets the midi instrument of all channels.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{tempo\_envelope}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.TempoEnvelope}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{core\_events.TempoEnvelope}}}}}) \textendash{} All Midi files should specify their tempo. The default
value of mutwo is 120 BPM (this is also the value that is assumed by any
midi\sphinxhyphen{}file\sphinxhyphen{}reading\sphinxhyphen{}software if no tempo has been specified). Tempo changes
are supported (and will be written to the resulting midi file).

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }        \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{pitch} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{c d e g a}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{split}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\sphinxstylestrong{Disclaimer:} when passing nested structures, make sure that the
nested object matches the expected type. Unlike other mutwo
converter classes (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.converters.core\_converters.TempoConverter}})
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.midi_converters:mutwo.midi_converters.EventToMidiFile}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EventToMidiFile}}}}} can’t convert infinitely nested structures
(due to the particular way how Midi files are defined). The deepest potential
structure is a {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SimultaneousEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SimultaneousEvent}}}}} (representing
the complete MidiFile) that contains {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SequentialEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SequentialEvent}}}}}
(where each \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEvent}} represents one MidiTrack) that contains
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_events:mutwo.core_events.SimpleEvent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.core\_events.SimpleEvent}}}}} (where each \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SimpleEvent}}
represents one midi note). If only one \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEvent}} is send,
this \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SequentialEvent}} will be read as one MidiTrack in a MidiFile.
If only one \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SimpleEvent}} get passed, this \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SimpleEvent}} will be
interpreted as one MidiEvent (note\_on and note\_off) inside one
MidiTrack inside one MidiFile.

Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.core_converters:mutwo.core_converters.abc.Converter}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Converter}}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Builds metrical indispensability for a rhythmical strata.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This technique has been described by Clarence Barlow in \sphinxtitleref{On the Quantification
of Harmony and Metre} (1992). The technique aims to model the weight
of single beats in a particular metre. It allocates each beat of a metre
to a specific value that describes the \sphinxtitleref{indispensability} of a beat: the higher the
assigned value, the more accented the beat.
\index{convert() (RhythmicalStrataToIndispensability method)@\spxentry{convert()}\spxextra{RhythmicalStrataToIndispensability method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/mutwo.music_converters:mutwo.music_converters.RhythmicalStrataToIndispensability.convert}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convert}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{rhythmical\_strata\_to\_convert}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Convert indispensability for each beat of a particular metre.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{rhythmical\_strata\_to\_convert}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Sequence}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}) \textendash{} The rhythmical strata defines
the metre for which the indispensability shall be calculated. The
rhythmical strata is a list of prime numbers which product is the
amount of available beats within the particular metre. Earlier
prime numbers in the rhythmical strata are considered to be more
important than later prime numbers.

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A tuple of a integer for each beat of the respective metre where
each integer describes how accented the particular beat is (the higher the
number, the more important the beat).

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
tuple{[}int, …{]}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar
This converter aims to adjust :class:{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}}music\_parameters.WesternPitch\textasciigrave{}s in
order to improve the quality of western notation created with these
pitches. Non\sphinxhyphen{}tonal music should be notated in a way to make it look as
tonal as possible (e.g. it should notate intervals musicians are used to,
it should avoid augmented or diminished intervals). The converter aims
to maximize simple intervals (without changing the actual pitch content)
by heuristic techniques. The converter may not return the best solution,
but a very good approximation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Disclaimer:}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This converter doesn’t work with microtonal pitches! This is due to the
fact that {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.music_parameters:mutwo.music_parameters.WesternPitchInterval}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.music\_parameters.WesternPitchInterval}}}}} doesn’t
support microtonal pitches yet.

This can
be a pitch object (any class that inherits from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.music\_parameters.abc.Pitch}})
or a list of pitch objects. Furthermore mutwo supports syntactic sugar
to convert other objects on the fly to pitch objects: Atring can be
read as pitch class names to build

objects. Other numbers (integer and float) will be read as pitch class numbers
to make {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/mutwo.music_parameters:mutwo.music_parameters.WesternPitch}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.music\_parameters.WesternPitch}}}}} objects.

\sphinxAtStartPar
By default mutwo doesn’t differentiate between Tones, Chords and
Rests, but rather simply implements one general class which can
represent any of the mentioned definitions (e.g. a NoteLike object
with several pitches may be called a ‘Chord’ and a NoteLike object
with only one pitch may be called a ‘Tone’).

\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{interval\_name\_or\_semitone\_count}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Union}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{[}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{core\_constants.Real}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{{]}}}) \textendash{} Can be either an interval name
(a string) or a number for semitones. When using an interval
name is should have the form: QUALITY\sphinxhyphen{}IS\_FALLING\sphinxhyphen{}TYPE, e.g. for having
a rising perfect fourth (where ‘fourth’ is the type and ‘perfect’ the
quality) you can write “p4”. For a falling perfect fourth it would
be “p\sphinxhyphen{}4”. The interval names are equal to the specification used
in the python library \sphinxhref{http://web.mit.edu/music21/}{music21}.
Please also consult the specification of the quality abbreviations at
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.music\_parameters.configurations.WESTERN\_PITCH\_INTERVAL\_QUALITY\_NAME\_TO\_ABBREVIATION\_DICT}}
and the specification of the \sphinxtitleref{is\sphinxhyphen{}interval\sphinxhyphen{}falling} indicator
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutwo.music\_parameters.configurations.FALLING\_WESTERN\_PITCH\_INTERVAL\_INDICATOR}}.
Both can be changed by the user. Default to ‘p1’.

\end{description}\end{quote}
